awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Trade-Offs Between Public Health Promotion and Legal Restrictions During the COVID-19 Pandemic
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, emergency laws and powers on a scale not seen since the 9/11/2001 terrorist attacks have been enacted, with implications for the everyday lives of Americans. Building on research on public perceptions of trade-offs between security protections and restrictions on personal freedoms in the post-9/11 environment, this project will use surveys that explore COVID-19 pandemic mitigation efforts that potentially constrain legal freedoms. As a result, this research will determine popular tolerance for perceived public health protections versus legal restrictions. 

Employing several waves of survey analyses of a nationally representative sample of the US population, this project will explore public views on government actions taken during the COVID-19 pandemic. Econometric models and machine learning techniques will be utilized to analyze the survey data. Findings will have implications on several theoretical literatures across disciplines, which will inform policy makers, scholars, and the public of the balance between competing public health imperatives and legal protections.

This project is jointly supported by the Law and Science Program (LS) and the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities (SMA) in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral & Economic Sciences (SBE).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project gathered and analyzed data that helps scholars and policymakers better understand how the US public perceives the relationship between public health measures to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and individual legal rights and freedoms. In particular, we examined how Americans interpret the appropriate balance between public health and civil liberties. To achieve these objectives, we administered a major nationally representative opinion survey (n=12,000) in two waves, during the early months of the pandemic, and then again six months later. Findings were contextualized alongside existing data regarding US public perceptions of security-rights tradeoffs in the national security and counterterrorism sphere to help illuminate similarities and differences between these domains. 


The intellectual merits of the project include substantial contributions to scholarly knowledge about the social and political determinants that shape public perceptions of controversial public policies during national emergencies. By taking a comparative approach that situated public opinion on public health policy during the pandemic alongside extant data on reactions to national security policy enacted during security crises, our research contributed to deepening understanding across issue areas and subfields of study. Moreover, our research leveraged cutting edge research methods, included advanced machine learning tools, to analyze our data, offering new ways to model and predict public opinion. 


The broader impacts of this research include illuminating problems that have been at the forefront of social and political debate in the US since the onset of the pandemic. Specifically, we have generated findings regarding vaccine acceptance and hesitancy, trust in science, blame attribution for perceived policy failure in a federal system, and public perceptions of public health mandates. This information provides policymakers and citizens insight into matters of intense public concern.


The outcomes of our project include a major new data set documenting American public opinion regarding legal rights and public health policy during the COVID-19 pandemic. This data will be used by scholars over the years to draw comparative insight into public reactions to various crises and emergencies. Moreover, we generated numerous scholarly articles, communicated findings to the public via news articles, and trained graduate students in research practices and methodologies.
